info.game_comments: IBM Challenge promo: "The Television Event of the Decade"

double_jeopardy_round: WHAT'S THE NAME OF YOUR UNION?

(1, 1).clue: Irving Berlin writes his first big hit, "Alexander's Ragtime Band"

(4, 1).clue: Tools, machinery & other implements for home & work bought at the store of the same name

(5, 1).clue: In 1932 Amelia Earhart became the first woman to fly over it alone & the first person of any sex to cross it by air twice

(6, 1).clue: Actor Dwayne Johnson has a half sleeve type of this; musician Travis Barker has 2 full ones

(1, 2).clue: General William Henry Harrison defeats the Shawnee Indians at the battle of Tippecanoe

(3, 2).clue: Dock's Oyster House--a New Jersey city

(4, 2).clue: When Alcatraz was a prison, these items with a metallic name were counted by officers after each meal

(5, 2).clue: An aviator contemporary of Amelia's was dubbed "Lucky" this; Amelia was "Lady" this

(6, 2).clue: Basketball sleeves contain this flexible segmented polyurethane fiber, an anagram of "expands"

(1, 3).clue: Explorer Henry Hudson is set adrift in his namesake bay by a mutinous crew & never seen again

(4, 3).clue: Malicious computer programs that are secretly installed on a computer to steal the user's private information

(5, 3).clue: Amelia Earhart was born in Atchison in this state; a bridge & an airport there are named for her

(6, 3).clue: This ornamental shoulder piece has an apostle in its name

(1, 4).clue: Oueen Anne of England establishes the Ascot horse races

(4, 4).clue: Caveat Emptor is usually translated as this 4-word English phrase

(5, 4).clue: Amelia once took this First Lady on a flight over Washington, D.C. while both were wearing evening gowns

(6, 4).clue: The French call this geographical feature "la Manche", which means "The Sleeve"

(1, 5).clue: In a warmup to his assault on Mexico, Cortes helps Velazquez conquer Cuba

(3, 5).clue: Casa Botin, located on Calle de los Cuchilleros (made famous in a Hemingway novel)

(4, 5).clue: Before it reaches Trenton, it skirts the Kittatinny Mountains & flows past Nockamixon Rocks

(5, 5).clue: Amelia was the first woman to receive this award, the DFC

(6, 5).clue: You can use sleeves to protect these items used in both Magic: The Gathering & Pokemon

(1, 1).clue: Although he completed a few musical pieces afterward, "William Tell" was his 38th & final opera

(2, 1).clue: He took a comedic turn in "The Other Guys" as Det. Terry Hoitz, who wants to "fly like a peacock"

(3, 1).clue: (Lindblad Expeditions naturalist Tom Ritchie delivers the clue from South Georgia.) Unlike the larger emperor, this second biggest species of penguin prefers the sub-Antarctic islands, like South Georgia, better than ice for forming its vast colonies

(5, 1).clue: His website says, "Dave lives in Miami... he has a son... and a daughter... neither of whom thinks he's funny"

(1, 2).clue: His last work was "Parsifal", which premiered at Bayreuth in 1882

(2, 2).clue: "Don't Forget The Lyrics!" or this Sugar Ray frontman who started hosting that show in 2010

(3, 2).clue: (Tom Ritchie of Lindblad Expeditions delivers the clue from South Georgia.) The island of South Georgia has no indigenous mammals, but reindeer were introduced here in 1911 to provide meat by Captain C.A. Larsen from this country

(4, 2).clue: The men & women assembling Mustangs & Malibus

(5, 2).clue: Thomas B. Thorpe wrote these alliterative, exaggerated stories, like "The Big Bear of Arkansas"

(6, 2).clue: The carrying capacity of a large ship is measured in this 7-letter word

(1, 3).clue: In 1751 he composed his last all-new composition, the oratorio "Jephtha"

(2, 3).clue: Mark Boal won 2 Oscars for this 2009 film about bomb defusers in Iraq

(3, 3).clue: (Tom Ritchie of Lindblad Expeditions delivers the clue from South Georgia.) South Georgia is the breeding ground for close to half the world's population of the largest pinniped--the Southern type of this seal now protected from hunting

(4, 3).clue: Approximately 2 million K-12 public school teachers in the U.S.

(5, 3).clue: Former Harvard Lampoon staffer Doug Kenney was the first editor of this magazine

(1, 4).clue: This Hungarian was just measures away from finishing his "Piano Concerto No. 3" when he died in New York in 1945

(2, 4).clue: Mark Mothersbaugh whipped it into shape as a member of this New Wave band

(3, 4).clue: The area around the island has some commercial fishing for the Patagonian this, aka Chilean sea bass

(5, 4).clue: Marrying Laura West made funny man S.J. Perelman brother-in-law to this author of 2 of Amer. lit's most depressing novels

(6, 4).clue: From the French for "training", it's an equestrian event

(1, 5).clue: Composed in 1795, his last symphony, No. 104 In D Major, is popularly known as "The London"

(2, 5).clue: Seen here, this actor is known for his work in indie films

(3, 5).clue: (Tom Ritchie of Lindblad Expeditions delivers the clue from South Georgia.)  South Georgia is the burial site for this explorer who made a grueling journey across the island after his ship, the Endurance, was trapped in pack ice

(5, 5).clue: Peace be with you!  2009 was the 150th birthday of this great Yiddish comic writer

(6, 5).clue: Within a circuit, it's calculated by the amount of current flow of 1 coulomb per second past a given point

(0, 0).clue: In this classic film, one of the characters tries to quote the Pythagorean theorem but gets it wrong
